                        tabs: [{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl15_divTabs_0","title":"April 21, 2020","content":"

Today at approximately noon, Governor Baker and DESE Commissioner Riley announced the closure of all public and private school buildings in Massachusetts for the remainder of the 19-20 school year.  However, we will continue to engage in remote learning for the duration of the 19-20 school year, as we have been since March. We are actively working with DESE Commissioner Riley and state superintendents to frame what remote learning for the remainder of the year should look like now that we know this closure will be extended




When we went into Phase 2 of remote learning April 6th, we built in a formal reflection on remote learning to date with our unions and community at large to be conducted the last week of April.  To that end, I sent out the recent parent ThoughtExchange last week and a staff ThoughtExchange goes out tomorrow.   I will also be conducting focus groups with special education parents,  and upperclassmen and senior students at NHS to inform this next extended Phase (3) of closure.  Please know that changing expectations is no small matter with the number of working parts, courses and service needs present in a given school day.  

Many have emailed in on the side of reducing the schedule and some adding to the schedule.  Working parents and stay-at-home parents have also emailed with their respective opinions.  Staff have spoken eloquently about how planning and preparation for every class is 2x the work it normally is—the design is different and the format is different.  Following up with missing students is different, and office hours are often spent helping our most fragile learners catch up and stay up given the difficulty of learning in a remote environment.  Desk-side support comes during office hours and many teachers have hundreds of students.  I encourage you to use the ThoughtExchange to express your ideas on remote learning and we will do our best to adjust our model as we can to continue to provide continuity, emotional support, rigorous academics and the space for all parents and staff the breathing space to parent and educate together.




Also, the MA Commissioner will issue new guidance on this phase (Phase 3) of remote learning and Phase 4 (school reopening).  For Phase 3, this may just be a blessing of what Natick has already implemented--permission to move forward with new material, special education services and to prioritize key standards-- so, as a state, we move together to address deficits and teaching gaps in a coordinated way.  In doing so, all students in MA will have access to resources and testing that accounts for this coordination. 




Phase 4 is something we have already been working on as noted in our school committee and parent chat meetings this month. We will bring to our community a curriculum standards coverage plan, a bridge program for the summer and how we will integrate lost learning time into the fall transition to new grades or new courses.  Before we can do that, however,  we have to digest upcoming state guidance and then make it work for Natick while we continue to follow state guidance on what’s next for closures and openings.  The good news is that Natick has a strong written curriculum with a guaranteed and viable scope and sequence for all grades and courses.  We can be very precise about learning needs and what has been covered in a given year.  We will bring you a smart transition plan.




While I understand that for many students and families, this final closure news is disappointing to hear, as the Governor stated we have to put safety first in this scenario. I empathize with our outgoing seniors who are mourning the traditional rites of passage with a spring prom and graduation to send them off into young adulthood. Rest assured we will leave no stone unturned in trying to reschedule or reshape these events. A meeting with senior student leadership is slated for this Friday for this reason.   




Also, many of our younger students are missing out on activities and transitions that enrich them and also feed their passions; likewise, wherever we can we will provide a reshaping or rescheduling of these events.




One of our core competencies in the Profile of a Natick Graduate is that we instill resilience in our students. This situation is testing our ability to teach and lead our students through uncertainty while remaining resilient, but we will weather things as a community.

Be well,




Anna



Anna P. Nolin, Ed.D.

Superintendent  of Schools

The secret of change is to focus all of your energy, not on fighting the old, but on building the new. – Socrates 




Natick Public Schools

www.natickps.org

annolin@natickps.org

Twitter@annapnolin

Not receiving the NPS Engage weekly e-blast? Click here for directions on how to subscribe!","active":true,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl15_divTabs_1","title":"April 9, 2020","content":"

We hope everyone is going into the weekend in good spirits. As we look ahead, we will begin phasing out our daily update and resume sending a weekly news email, with some changes. In a previous update, I mentioned that we heard and read feedback about how the schools were communicating with you and we listened.




Starting tomorrow, and moving forward, we will begin sending a consolidated weekly district email blast, called NPS Engage, to families with links to each school blast that is now featured on the front page of the school website. This will ensure that you’re able to read all important information for the upcoming week, while avoiding the email fatigue and inbox cluster that was expressed in your input to us.




Our consolidated district email is a new initiative, and with any new initiative it takes time to get into a good routine. Our staff have been working diligently behind the scenes to make the rollout of this new communication process seamless. Moving forward, this new strategy should provide families with an easier way to locate information from your school by receiving a single email and always using the website as the reference point where the information is located. 




As always we appreciate your feedback and encourage you to reach out to us using ‘Speak Up, Natick!’




RECAP FROM LAST NIGHT’S VIRTUAL OFFICE HOUR

Here is a video of last night’s live stream parent talk on remote learning: 

Recording of the special education Parent Chat 4/8/20




And the slide deck used in recent parent chats: Remote Learning Slide Deck Used in Parent Chats




Translated documents aligned with the above overview in all languages will be forthcoming in upcoming blasts.




NEF SPONSORS NPS STAFF PERSON HARDSHIP FUND

Want to help NPS staff who might be suffering hardship due to furlough or other employment reductions? Contact the Natick Education Foundation at https://natickedfoundation.org/?page_id=531 where you can donate to the NPS Staff Hardship fund.




SCHOOL FIELDS, TRACK AT MEMORIAL, AND PARKING LOT AT KMS

Please note that the Board of Health has now authorized Natick Staff  to patrol these areas and to disperse groups of people who congregate there to play.  Individuals respecting social distancing can continue to shoot hoops, and use the track, but groups may not.  Please advise your children and community members.  We will station staff to visit and dispel groups from the site on school grounds:  KMS parking lot, NHS football field, all Memorial fields and track, Coolidge Ball Courts and Memorial Baseball fields/area.  School discipline may be issued.




To those of you celebrating Easter this weekend, have a nice holiday and everyone, enjoy the long weekend!




Anna



Anna P. Nolin, Ed.D.

Superintendent  of Schools

The secret of change is to focus all of your energy, not on fighting the old, but on building the new. – Socrates

SPECIAL EDUCATION OFFICE HOURS

TODAY! → Wednesday, April 8, 2020, Virtual Special Education Office Hours/Community Chat, 6:30pm

Learn more about our Link to the Phase 2 remote learning overview from the April 3rd update: https://bit.ly/npsremotelearning2020




We apologize for the conflict of parent special education chat and the first night of Passover.  We wanted to ensure good information was available to all special education families prior to the start of Phase 2 services (4/9/2020).  Both parent chats are recorded for your convenience and we hope parents will reach out with questions.

Translation During Today’s Virtual Parent Office Hour and Community Chat

We have worked to enhance live translation capabilities for families to participate in these live sessions. See below for the translation details and information.




For real time text and voice translation of this meeting:

    
Click this link to join the conversation:  https://translate.it/LYDCH
    
Type your name
    
Choose your language
    
Press Enter


Once you are in the meeting:

    
Go to the settings (it looks like a wheel in the top right corner next to your name) 
    
Here you can choose “play speech output” to hear the meeting for many languages. 
    
You can also choose to  have the English message typed with your chosen language. 
    
When the meeting is over you can save the transcribed text if you want.

Dear Natick Families,




We have a few updates and reminders for you below.




APRIL BREAK PLANNING

The School Committee will make a decision at its April 13 meeting relative to April Break. Please fill out this survey to inform them.  April Break Planning Survey (one question).  

 

REMOTE LEARNING PHASE 2:  PARENT MEETINGS

Tuesday, April 7, 2020, Virtual Parent Office Hours/Community Chat 6:30pm

Wednesday, April 8, 2020, Virtual Special Education Office Hours/Community Chat, 6:30pm




PASSOVER

Wednesday, April 8, marks the start of Passover. Consistent with how we operate and advise our faculty and staff when school is open to in-person gathering, we have advised that our typical policies on not assigning and expecting homework on these religious holidays has been shared with our entire organization.




VIRTUAL SCHOOL COMMITTEE MEETING - APRIL 6, 2020 - 7:00 P.M.

In accordance with an executive order from Governor Baker, the School Committee meeting will be held virtually on the Zoom video-conferencing platform. 

Agenda: 

This meeting will be video recorded through zoom and posted asap after the meeting to Pegasus TV channel for public review (Meeting Agenda). Below we have provided the login instructions to join the Zoom meeting 

 

Online: 

Link: https://bccte.zoom.us/j/5082294832

Meeting ID: 508 229 4832

 

One tap mobile:

If viewing this email on a mobile device, by clicking on one number below the call will auto-dial and login for you.

 

+13126266799,,5082294832# US (Chicago)

+16468769923,,5082294832# US (New York)

 

Call-in options (use any one below):

Call in is for listen only services.

 

+1 646 876 9923 US

+1 253 215 8782 US

+1 301 715 8592 US

Meeting ID: 508 229 4832

 

Please note - you will only be able to ask questions through the Zoom chat feature if you join via video. If you join via phone (as listed above), you will be in listen-only mode and will need to submit questions through email to the School Committee chair Julie McDonough, at jmcdonough@natickps.org. 




REDHAWK MEMORIES

NHS sophomore, Ella O'Connor, has created Redhawk Memories, a website and Instagram account where Natick community members can memorialize loved ones lost during this pandemic (due to COVID-19 or other reasons). Because families and friends are unable to honor those lost in traditional ways at this time, we hope that by sharing their stories, photos, and videos in two easily-accessible ways, those dealing with grief will be able to feel the community support they are unable to receive in person.




Website: bit.ly/redhawkmemories

Email: redhawkmemories@gmail.com

Instagram: @RedhawkMemories




To successfully launch this memorial page, we are asking for your help to spread the word. Sharing our page with anyone you can, whether it be with students, family, friends, would be greatly appreciated. The loved ones featured need not be Natick residents themselves; they just have to have a connection to someone in our community -- to a student, a community member, a school or town employee.




DONATIONS

We so appreciate the offer to donate items from your homes (laptops, masks, supplies, etc) to support those in need.  At this time, given the manner of virus spread, we cannot accept donations from homes.  However, if you would like to make a donation to NEF’s newly created Hardship Fund--a fund to support educators who may be negatively impacted financially by the closure, we would appreciate it!




FIELDS AND TRACK AT MEMORIAL AND PARKING LOT AT KMS

Please note that the Board of Health has now authorized me to patrol these areas and to disperse groups of people who congregate there to play.  Individuals respecting social distancing can continue to shoot hoops, and use the track, but groups may not.  Please advise your children and community members.  We will station staff to visit and dispel groups from the site.  




Anna



Anna P. Nolin, Ed.D.

Superintendent  of Schools

The administrative leadership team has issued updates about the overarching Remote Learning Program and Update on Special Education for Natick Families during closure.

Please visit the Remote Learning Program page to learn more.

Today, we held a district-wide meeting to update faculty and staff on our remote learning expectations to support students during closure.  We will be working to bring you those updates soon and will present them at our school committee meeting Monday evening, April 7.  Below is the agenda and log in information for the upcoming meeting. 




We look forward to continuing to support our learners PK-12 with increased service and resource time. 

Mobile technology deployments continue to bring technology to critical need families and we are rolling through your requests.  




Virtual School Committee Meeting - April 7, 2020 - 7:00 p.m.

In accordance with an executive order from Governor Baker, the School Committee meeting will be held virtually on the Zoom video-conferencing platform. 

Agenda: 

This meeting will be video recorded through zoom and posted asap after the meeting to Pegasus TV channel for public review (Meeting Agenda). Below we have provided the login instructions to join the Zoom meeting 

 

Online: 

Link: https://bccte.zoom.us/j/5082294832

+1 301 715 8592 US

Meeting ID: 508 229 4832

 

Please note - you will only be able to ask questions through the Zoom chat feature if you join via video. If you join via phone (as listed above), you will be in listen-only mode and will need to submit questions through email to the School Committee chair Julie McDonough, at jmcdonough@natickps.org. 




Upcoming SPARK Kindness Online Connection Opportunities

Though we are physical distancing, SPARK Kindness cares about you and wants to connect! Through these are challenging times we know that we are stronger, kinder, and more resilient together. SPARK has developed updated online programming, resources and opportunities for connection so that we can stand together while we stay apart. Let’s celebrate our resilience and connection together — learn more by viewing the SPARK brochure.




Anna



Anna P. Nolin, Ed.D.

Superintendent  of Schools

The secret of change is to focus all of your energy, not on fighting the old, but on building the new. – Socrates

","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl21_divTabs_2","title":"April 1, 2020","content":"

We have obtained Japanese and Vietnamese speaker assistance—thank you to those volunteers! 




In addition, we met with our teachers’ union leadership to address the changing working conditions surrounding moving to a remote learning environment and have been checking in with families about their remote learning needs, including checking on students who have been absent from class chats to date and helping families with English as a second language challenges.  We also continue to deploy technology resources to homes on a rolling basis. There are no additional updates to the education environment as of today.  




Many of you have asked about refunds for ASAP tuition, ASAP enrichment, and buses.  As we sort through these issues, we will come back to you with next steps.  Without ASAP and busing in session, we have to work with our contracts and staff to handle these programs, and relative to busing, we will calculate any refunds based on the date of return to school.  As you know the Governor will decide closer to May 4 (the current end date for closure) if the closure is extended or not.   We ask for your patience as we wade through the sheer amount of guidance on emergency funding, expectations for payment of staff and payment of contracts.  An email to preschool parents is forthcoming.




I hope that you are all healthy and safe and adapting to this new routine and learning environment.  It’s kindness week, and we are sharing some info about Kindness Week, and I can honestly say that I have seen so many kind moments in the time since closure. Notes, gestures--moments of care and love from our community that affirm my love for this town.  While closure will bring ups and downs throughout it’s the spirit of kindness, flexibility and assumption of good intentions that will get us through.




I’ve been visiting classes online and it’s been nice to see you all as you “pop” into view!




Anna



Anna P. Nolin, Ed.D.

Superintendent  of Schools

The secret of change is to focus all of your energy, not on fighting the old, but on building the new. – Socrates 




Natick Public Schools

annolin@natickps.org

Accessing NPS Technology Support

There are no new updates from the school system today!  




In an effort to increase our translation support for families, we are looking for translators who speak Japanese and Vietnamese.  If you can provide these services, please email me directly annolin@natickps.org.




I have met with all of our district curriculum leaders and administrators in the past two days to put in place a curriculum coverage and transition document to ensure as we head through this year and the start of the next school year that we are tracking what material has and has not been covered in each grade level.  This school closure is an event that will present challenges for all of our schools and grade levels and we want you to know we are creating plans to address these coverage issues.  Updates to our learning plans will be shared in the coming week.  




We also wanted you to know that you may be wondering why you haven’t heard from your principals directly since the closure.  We have been in our pandemic response incident command communication structure and in order to assure you are not overwhelmed with administrator directives, we have streamlined into one district communication.  As we head into the coming weeks, we will be sharing a new streamlined email communication system from all of our buildings.  We took community feedback from our recent Parent Town Hall, ThoughtExchange Survey from February (summary report included here) and focus groups.  We incorporated your feedback and starting April 10th, we will bring you that new streamlined manner of communication from the district.  You will have more control over the content you see and we will eliminate multiple emails with repeated content.




We look forward to your feedback on it in the coming months and thank you for sharing your ideas with us so far.





Hope you are all doing well!

Anna



Anna P. Nolin, Ed.D.

Superintendent  of Schools

The secret of change is to focus all of your energy, not on fighting the old, but on building the new. – Socrates

Dear Natick Families,

 

Hoping this email finds you well after a nice weekend. As we continue moving forward, below are our community updates.

Virtual School Committee Meeting - March 30, 2020 - 7:00 p.m.

In accordance with an executive order from Governor Baker, the School Committee meeting will be held virtually on the Zoom video-conferencing platform. 

Agenda: 

This meeting will be video recorded through zoom and posted asap after the meeting to Pegasus TV channel for public review (Meeting Agenda). Below we have provided the login instructions to join the Zoom meeting 

 

Online: 

Link: https://bccte.zoom.us/j/5082294832

Meeting ID: 508 229 4832

 

One tap mobile:

If viewing this email on a mobile device, by clicking on one number below the call will auto-dial and login for you.

 

+13126266799,,5082294832# US (Chicago)

+16468769923,,5082294832# US (New York)

 

Call-in options (use any one below):

Call in is for listen only services.

 

+1 646 876 9923 US

+1 253 215 8782 US

+1 301 715 8592 US

Meeting ID: 508 229 4832

 

Please note - you will only be able to ask questions through the Zoom chat feature if you join via video. If you join via phone (as listed below), you will be in listen-only mode and will need to submit questions through email to the School Committee chair at jmcdonough@natickps.org. 

 

A few other items to consider when joining the virtual meeting:

    
Video may be slow based upon the number of participants in the Zoom meeting
    
Participants will be muted and video will be turned off
    
Public Speak will be through the chair and she will read any public speak documents sent to her per the meeting posting up to 3-min in length
    
Public participation on agenda items/the business items of the school committee meeting, in keeping with policy, will be at the chair’s discretion--the public should submit questions through the chat feature of the Zoom meeting and the chair will address.
    
Questions at this meeting should be regarding policy, budget, and the performance of the superintendent (the purview of school committee)


Feel Good Updates

The Wilson librarian is running an event for Read Across America Day and wants your ﻿selfies of you reading! https://docs.google.com/document/d/12ButZpt9cvy_BDRFtlWjb0JOFYvj_Wk1kuMeR8SbCok/edit?ts=5e814a30

 

NHS student Charlotte Gagliardi has been sewing masks for healthcare workers at her home. With the delay of costumes for spring sing and the drama, Charlotte was looking for an outlet for her sewing skills and she channeled that into making masks for the frontline and at risk people! Charlotte is pictured below with the masks she created. 

 





Students taking Video Production at NHS put together a PSA video, "We're All In This Together", to help stop the spread of this virus. Check it out and share: https://youtu.be/vTf1y2_fQXw!

 

Stay safe and healthy,



Anna P. Nolin, Ed.D.

Today, we participated in a state-wide conference call with the MA Commissioner of Education where we received further guidance on remote learning and services for children.  Our team is now meeting and coordinating on the directives, and we will come back to you within a few days with any updates to our educational environment.




Below I’ve posted a few reminders for you to begin preparing for next week, as we go into the weekend.




REVIEW THE SCHEDULE FOR NEXT WEEK

You will find the daily schedule for your student(s) below. Your classroom teachers will also email you and/or your child with further details about enrichment and scheduling, however, the links posted below are here for your reference.  Please review the alternating daily class chats/office hours to ensure you don’t miss a day!




Preschool Schedule

Elementary School

Middle School

High School




If you miss a classroom session, it will be recorded and your student(s) can access it at a later time.




If your child’s teachers have you visiting a class resource you have already used (Seesaw, Dojo, etc.) just use it as you always have.  They may have placed their enrichment resources, Video Google Meeting Links and saved video recordings in these resources.  Refer to teacher emails for guidance.




COMPLETE OUR PARENT SURVEY!

As mentioned yesterday, we are gathering feedback and hope that you’ll take 5 minutes to complete our Online Enrichment & Office Hours Survey.




As we go into the weekend, I want to leave things on a high note and hope you’ll enjoy this virtual concert from Natick’s very own, Scalestorm: https://youtu.be/5denATwHFvY!




Stay safe and healthy,



Anna P. Nolin, Ed.D.

Superintendent  of Schools

We hope that our first day of teacher office hours and small group meetings went well from your perspective.  Our staff met at the end of the day today and teachers LOVED checking in and meeting with your children. 




We are anxiously awaiting a meeting with the MA Commissioner of Education tomorrow to give us further guidance on remote learning and services for children.  We will come back to you within a few days with any updates to our educational environment.  Meanwhile, let’s all prepare for day 2 of classroom chats and enrichment opportunities!




Technology requests that have been made through today have been time-stamped and will be addressed in order of receipt.  Moving forward, please do not email us to check on the status of your technology device request, we will get back to you based on technology device availability. 




COMPLETE OUR PARENT SURVEY!

As mentioned yesterday, we are gathering feedback and hope that you’ll take 5 minutes to complete our Online Enrichment & Office Hours Survey




A few other announcements:




Interface Mental Health Services

The William James College INTERFACE Referral Service is here to support you. They are continuing to operate on their regular schedule from remote locations and have created several resources you may find useful:

    

    
A web page of resources updated regularly
    
    

    
A source page for telehealth services 
    
    

    
Information regarding the efficacy of telehealth
    
    

    
A guide to help callers understand more about telehealth, and how to best prepare for a session
    





Incoming Kindergarten Information (for 2020-2021)

Currently, elementary principals are redesigning the incoming kindergarten orientation process to meet physical distancing standards. Stay tuned for updates in this area.




Stay safe and healthy,



Anna P. Nolin, Ed.D.

Today was a very successful start to our online educational enrichment! Thank you for all the lovely notes telling us about the day.  We know there were some hiccups and we know there will be challenges as we now head into an extended closure period.




As you may know, this afternoon Governor Baker signed an order that all Massachusetts schools will remain closed until Monday, May 4th.




As the Governor and Education Commissioner Riley announced today, the Department of Elementary & Secondary Education (DESE) is developing educational programming guidelines to help students remain engaged in learning during this time out of school. After we review the teaching and learning guidance that the DESE will be sharing with districts tomorrow, we will follow these guidelines and work cooperatively with the Education Association of Natick to develop remote learning plans for our students. Until we receive greater guidance, the program of enrichment opportunities that began today will be in play.  




The DESE is expected to communicate directly with families in the coming days about their educational plans for students, particularly for students who do not have technology or internet access at home. Please know that we will continue to remain in contact with families and staff throughout this school closure period.




Here is the link to the enrichment program overview.  We include it so you can have easy access to it for the upcoming days of enrichment.




Tomorrow we will be including a feedback survey for parents to fill out about the home enrichment experiences of this week.  




Stay safe and healthy,



Anna P. Nolin, Ed.D.

Superintendent  of Schools

The secret of change is to focus all of your energy, not on fighting the old, but on building the new. – Socrates

Our virtual/remote enrichment opportunities start tomorrow, Wednesday, March 25th! 




We strongly encourage participation so that students connect with their teachers and we all become accustomed to this new method of communication and interaction. For an explanation of the plan, please review this PPT presentation. (start on Slide #7)

 



 

Daily Schedule

You will find the daily schedule for your student here; your classroom teachers will have also emailed you/and/or your child with further detail. But here’s a good general overview, especially for PK-6 families, whose students and families are not as used to learning with technology as our older students.




Preschool Schedule

Elementary School

Middle School

High School




If you miss a classroom session, it will be recorded and you can access it at a later time.




If your child’s teachers have you visiting a class resource you have already used (Seesaw, Dojo, etc.) just use it as you always have.  They may have placed their enrichment resources, Video Google Meeting Links and saved video recordings in these resources.  Refer to teacher emails for guidance.




No matter what age student you have, all of the resources you need are listed on the Launch Page Below.

 



 

District Launch Page -- ONE STOP WITH LINKS TO ALL TEACHER & STUDENT SERVICES RESOURCES




District Launch Page

All teachers will place relevant links and information here. You will also receive an email from your teacher by Tuesday night, March 24th with specific information.




Student Privacy and Security

Google Meetings, recordings and other resources are for the use of the class with whom the teacher shared.  We have done our best to protect the resources where children are involved, and during this week of transition, we ask you to avoid moving through the resources for teachers who are not your children’s teacher--to help decrease the possibility for misinterpretation or intrusion to occur.  

 



 

All Students Have a NatickPS Gmail Address

(Email is not live for PK-age13 students to email but it is live for logging into Google)




You will be able to use your child’s email address to gain access to all Google applications--even if your child doesn’t have an active account (PreK -grade 7 families).  Parents, unless you have your own google account, you will unlikely be able to access the resources from your private non-google email addresses.  These are security measures for our students. Email addresses are in your child’s information in iPASS.




To access Google Classroom (classroom.google.com) enter the student email and student password on the login screen. Student passwords are nps<studentid> by default e.g.:  nps1234567. To find your student’s email, please go to iParent and click on “Biographical” (see image below). Teachers using Classroom before Covid closure will already have enrolled your child so the tile will appear. For those teachers launching this week, you will have received code to login. Please note: not all teachers are using Google Classroom. Need More Help with Google Classroom? Here is a quick introduction to get started. 



 



 

Virtual Health Clinic with Natick School Nurses

Our nursing staff will be offering remote clinic hours to the NPS community: Monday through Friday; 10 a.m. until 12 p.m.




Nurses are available to check-in with students via EMAIL, PHONE, or GOOGLE MEET. Please email your school's nurse to coordinate a check-in time for remote clinic hours.

 



 

Technology

If you need assistance with technology, our Tech Team has developed a helpful guide for contacting the Parent Help Desk (parentsupport@natickps.org)  and/or instructions on how to use borrowed devices.




Please know that we have done our best to turn our brick-and-mortar core values into a virtual learning environment.  Our work this week is to become accustomed to the technology and the video conferencing and we will work out the kinks as we go.  Many families are still trying to locate working technology and we are working to get our English Language Learner families up to speed as well.  




More to come!



Anna P. Nolin, Ed.D.

Superintendent  of Schools

Governor Baker’s Executive Order

Today, 3/23/20, Governor Baker issued an executive order on Essential Services and Revised Gathering Limits. Particularly important in this order is item #3, which states:

 

Limitations on Gatherings

Gatherings of more than 10 people are prohibited throughout the Commonwealth. Gatherings subject to this Order include, without limitation, community, civis, public, leisure, faith-based, or sporting events, concerts, conferences, conventions, fundraisers, parades, fairs, festivals, weddings, funerals, and any similar event or activity that brings together more than 10 person in any confined indoor or outdoor space. This limitation shall not apply to the operations or activities of any business or organization in its provision or delivery of COVID-19 Essential Services.

 

This Order does not prohibit gatherings of more than 10 people in unenclosed, outdoor space such as a park, athletic field, or parking lot.

 

Athletic and recreational activities that bring participants into close physical contact are prohibited even when involving 10 or fewer people and regardless of where conducted.

 

This means no group fitness, basketball games or touch football anywhere.  Please respect social distancing expectations ordered by the governor.

This block of programs will run from noon to 5pm ET, and was put together for middle and high school students. Younger children can continue to tune into WGBH 2 and WGBX 44 during the day and WGBH Kids 24/7. Note that each program has associated optional related resources for online learning.




View the WGBH Distance Learning Center (broadcast schedule): https://www.wgbh.org/distance-learning-center/broadcast




Thanks for you attention and engagement as we navigate things together.

Thank you to the Natick SEPAC organization for connecting with us about emerging questions regarding our special education students and how the days ahead (during school closure) will look for them.







We want to thank you for your continued patience as we work through all of the details in an effort to provide educational enrichment opportunities to all students.  The enrichment that we are developing for our special education students is a work-in-progress that will certainly give high quality opportunities in academics, social skills, speech, OT,  PT, assistive technology, augmentative communication, behavioral strategies, and more. Please bear with us, as we just proposed this to our staff no more than 2 days ago and they are working diligently to realize the vision. 







We are confident in the message that was sent to special education families on March 16.  In our message, we outlined both, the guidance we have received from the Commissioner of Education, Associate Commissioner, Governor, and the Office of Special Education Services, as well as the fact that—although we are not required to provide Free And Appropriate Public Education (FAPE) during closure—we will be providing educational enrichment opportunities for our special education students.







We understand that all parents may have anxiety over what the upcoming days will bring.  Our goal is to present a comprehensive package that is easy to understand, communicate, and leave little room for questions: this can not be done until the teachers have the time to do their magic.  To that end, we will be presenting at the School Committee on Monday night regarding all educational opportunities, including those for special education students. We invite you to join Dr. Nolin and Mr. Luff during scheduled office hours on Monday (3/23) or Tuesday (3/24).

    
Virtual School Committee Meeting: Monday, March 23, 2020, 7pm (Agenda: https://natickschools.novusagenda.com/agendapublic/)
    
Superintendent Office Hours for Families:  Monday March 23, 12:30pm (Dr. Nolin Parent  Virtual Office Hours:  12:30pm)
    
Superintendent Office Hours for Families:  Tuesday, March 24, 5:30pm (Dr. Nolin Parent Virtual Office Hours 5:30pm)


Please know this: Natick is not acting conservatively in any way.  Conservative would mean we would not be planning to provide any opportunities to special education students, other than for those who are in Out-of-District programs.  This is not—and would never be—the case.







Again, we appreciate your patience in these uncertain times.

 



Timothy Luff

It has been a whirlwind of a couple of weeks!  Thank you for your patience as we designed, trained and implemented an entire virtual educational enrichment environment in the last week!  With the extended closure of school, we will be providing continuity of educational experiences for our students in the form of enrichment opportunities. Those opportunities will include:

    
CLASSROOM CHATS:  using  Google Meet Video conferencing (now free to all US schools), 
    
EDUCATIONAL ENRICHMENT OPPORTUNITIES: online using a combination of Google Apps/Docs, Google Classroom, Seesaw, Moodle, and other tools already in use by classroom and specialized teachers.
    
OFFICE HOURS: in a manner described and communicated by classroom teachers who interact with your child.
    
INDIVIDUAL AND/OR SMALL GROUP MEETINGS: using Sign-Up Genius, YouCanBookMe (HS only), Google Calendar, phone and email. Guidance Counselors, social workers and psychologists will be available for “check-ins” to assess student needs during this time; these are NOT counseling sessions but we will support student needs as we discover them. 





The Massachusetts Commissioner of Education and MA education laws are quite clear: when school is not officially in session, we cannot equitably provide FAPE (Free and Appropriate Public Education) for all students with all needs.  Therefore, it is important to understand that we are NOT holding virtual school.  


Our Core Values and Enrichment

We will be using these first several days to fine tune how to best maintain meaningful connections with our students during this extended absence from our regular routines. We understand that the uncertainty of this new plan is likely causing some feelings of worry. This is true for all of us! Please know, we are working diligently to help scaffold this new program for students and parents alike. As we move forward we will send additional communications.  We appreciate your continued patience as we adjust to this new reality! For this next phase of community life to be effective, we must enact the following community norm: Flexibility and Assumption of Positive Intentions.  







We are all doing the best we can to adapt to a new, unusual and never-forecasted situation.  Please assume the best of us and we will do the same. This implementation is new, raw, sloppy and there will be new details we have not been able to predict or iron out.  We have completely reshaped our educational environment in a matter of days.







    
Keeping our overarching goals in mind will be an important key to success. We will strive to:​

    
    
        
Keep your students engaged and learning.

        
        
Maintain flexibility for families and teachers (who are at home with their families)  to tweak learning plans if needed.

        
        
Preserve important relationships between students and teachers (their trusted adults)  #RelationshipsMatter

        
    
    
    
The importance of a schedule is essential, for both adults and students. We will offer guidance and support with this. Because each family’s situation is unique, and we know parents are battling their childcare and work needs, feel free to adjust the schedule to fit your family. There is no right way to manage online enrichment. Keep in mind our educators are experiencing the same—juggling a 4-year-old while you’re trying to connect on your community chat may have some hiccups.  We’ll need your flexibility, patience, and understanding—this is new for everyone.

    
    
In addition to the educational value of schooling, the daily routine of school provides all students with two benefits essential to their psychological safety: STRUCTURE and CONNECTEDNESS.  Psychologists recognize that structure and connectedness offers children comfort and predictability -- two things that I think we can all acknowledge are in short supply these days. While the Enrichment

    
    
Opportunities  your child’s teacher(s) have developed will serve them well educationally, they also offer your student the structure and connectedness they need during these uncertain times.  

    
    
Our aim is to design plans that require the same parent involvement as typical homework; where parents can help students with their schedule, time management and organization; however, the majority of work itself should be able to be done independently by students.

    
    
Students should access teacher office hours if they are struggling.  You should not tear your hair out trying to instruct.

    
    
        
Despite our best efforts, there will likely be glitches at the outset and we ask for your patience as we work them out.

        
        
Finally, we are realistic about technology use and understand there are parts we will have to troubleshoot. If your child is having technology problems, please use this guide to assist you:  Technical Support During Closure (Virtual Help Desk). Our live technicians are available during the noted hours.

        
    
    




This is Not Virtual School—it can’t be!

The online educational enrichment opportunities we will provide during this virus closure should not be seen as a replication of the traditional, in-person school day. Rather, it’s a way to provide continuity of learning for our students during this uncertain time. 







If your child receives special education services, please read this memo that went out to all parents on March 16:  Parent Communication Regarding Special Education 3-16-2020. We have carefully crafted these enrichment activities to meet the needs of all of our learners, including those who receive special education and others with diverse learning needs. For our English Language Learner students, additional translation and accessibility tools and services are pending. We have designed learning experiences and training to position our district well in the event of a longer closure or if the Department of Elementary and Secondary Education allows us to provide virtual instruction in some form. If the directive about virtual instruction changes, we will notify the community as we have been in our daily updates. 







Natick’s Educational Enrichment Opportunities are age-appropriate learning activities specifically selected or developed by your child’s teacher or related service provider that are designed to achieve any number of goals, including: maintaining current academic progress, reinforcing skills already taught, or discovering or exploring something they are passionate about. 







What Will This Experience Be Like For Us? 

As stated earlier in this memo, we can provide opportunities for enrichment but we cannot continue to teach our classes. This is due to legal mandates requiring us to provide free and appropriate public education and the directive provided by the current MA Commissioner of Education. The resources, instruction, interaction or activities we provide will not replace our typical curriculum; it cannot be what we would have taught were we in school. We have to be prepared, therefore, to go back to school in three weeks and pick up where you left off March 7th. This does, however, present an opportunity for students to practice the skills they have developed to deepen their understanding of the instruction they have already received. Think of these educational opportunities in the same way we do summer reading --we provide them, we talk about them, we do activities around them, we write about them, but we cannot grade students on the work and when kids return to school, they are afforded the time to “make up” and complete the reading and accompanying work.  The work can enhance, extend, and enrich the subjects and curriculum we are teaching in actual classes; however, at this time cannot be formal instruction on those subjects and curriculum.







Do These Classes Count?

The future of the school year is uncertain.  These experiences should be taken seriously by students and parents alike.  The experiences will not be graded in a traditional fashion, rather, they will be given a credit/no credit designation within the teachers’ records.  Feedback may be given during office hours. We are unsure of the status of school at this time and we may have to use these experiences to allow students to gain credit for completion of this school year, although we are not yet authorized by the state to do so.  Students and parents should take them seriously and give the best effort possible. We will provide enrichment for whoever shows up to our classroom chat sessions/classes and office hours. We have provided you some best practice norms and professional conduct advice (see norms and rules documents below) to make this a more comfortable experience.  Classroom chats will be hosted in Google Go-Meet! We will record the video classroom chats and include enrichment opportunity links using email, websites, Google Classroom pages and Moodle sites. Links to individual teacher sites and materials will be aggregated by department leaders and/or principals so parents can have one launch page to find information for the total district (please refer to your email for this link).  This page will not be opened to you, the parents and families until Wednesday, March 24, 2020, to give teachers time to prepare their materials.







WHAT ABOUT: Grades, Tests & MCAS? 

Teachers will not be grading during this time. Teachers and other school-based staff will be working from home and will be staying connected with your student during this shutdown period.  You can support your children by guiding them to use this non-instructional time productively and help them dedicate a portion of time each day to do work that was required prior to March 7.  Again, you should receive an email update from your school principal containing additional details on what this will look like by Saturday evening. Should we return to traditional school, instruction will pick up pre-COVID-19 closure impacts, on March 7th, to ensure all students have the required instruction.  At the time of this memo, dictates on MCAS and other testing are in flux. We will update you as we become aware of new developments. HS parents, see your schedule page for updates by grade level on important grade-specific planning.







WHAT ABOUT: Make-Up Work?  

Grades were frozen as of March 8, 2020.  If students were out prior to March 8 or have make-up work from class prior to March 8, they can hand in the missing work and can use office hours to catch up and gain help on the missing work or missed instruction prior to March 8.  No retakes or rewrites will be available at this time. When we reopen, teachers will consider if they will allow retakes and revisions based on their previously established processes.







How do we get started?

For our PK-6 learners who do not have email addresses or use Google Classroom in their classes, staff will communicate these opportunities to parents and their email addresses since children do not have email accounts







Below, we have outlined our expectations for these experiences and the schedules for each level for ALL.







WASH YOUR HANDS, RESPECT SOCIAL DISTANCING EXPECTATIONS—EVERYWHERE—DO NOT COME TO PLAYGROUNDS, FIELDS AND OTHER COMMUNITY AREAS!  THIS IS SERIOUS!















Important Links for Virtual Engagement:

    
Norms (the Rules) for Families and Students During Classroom Chats!
    
Family Instructions for Joining/Rejoin a Google Meet Live or Recorded Video Chat


Important Links by Level:  

    
High School Schedule (and grade specific guidance updates)
    
Middle School Schedule
    
Elementary School Schedule
    
Preschool Schedule
    
Supplementary Resources Provided By MA Department of Education:

    The MA Department of Education is also working with WGBH, Univision, and Telemundo to provide resources through the television for multiple languages.  We will update you as this becomes available.






Need more technology?

We have had many emails today that parents missed technology pick up or are unsure of the required technology specifications.  We do not have enough laptops for every child in NPS to gain access to a laptop, however, we will do our best to come close. We are asking families who have adequate technology to forgo requesting technology support; but if you need it, let us know.  Similarly, we loaned hotspots to staff and students who do not have technology at home, but we worry there is a greater need. Please email our Speak Up, Natick! portal if you need either of these.  We are working on mobile technology deployment in the next wave, unless state mandates dictate that we cannot.







District Office Hours (for Families and NHS Students):

If you want to have questions answered or provide feedback, joint us for these livestream events next week (Instructions for joining office Hours):



    
Virtual School Committee Meeting: Monday, March 23, 2020, 7pm (Agenda: https://natickschools.novusagenda.com/agendapublic/)
    
Superintendent Office Hours for Families:  Monday March 23, 12:30pm (Dr. Nolin Parent  Virtual Office Hours:  12:30pm)
    
Superintendent Office Hours for Families:  Tuesday, March 24, 5:30pm Dr. Nolin Parent Virtual Office Hours 5:30pm
    
Superintendent Office Hours for NHS Students:  Tuesday, March 24, 7pm Dr. Nolin NHS Student Virtual Office Hours 7pm
    
Or, reach out to us using Speak Up,Natick!: www.natickps.org/contact_us/speakupnatick

    






This is a lot to digest, please read and reread.  Watch our Monday meeting and come to our office hours.  We can answer questions then. Enrichment time begins Wednesday, March 25, 8 am according to the provided schedules.  We care about you and your children and see you as our partners in education as we move through this unprecedented time.







Sincerely,



Anna P. Nolin, Ed.D.

Superintendent  of Schools

The secret of change is to focus all of your energy, not on fighting the old, but on building the new. – Socrates

We are in full swing doing faculty training around our online educational enrichment opportunities set to launch next week, Wednesday, March 25, 2020! Although the circumstances around this are not ideal, we know Natick is a community that continues to find innovative ways to handle challenges and this situation will be no different. Below I’m providing guidance about our school pickup day tomorrow. Parent guidance on upcoming educational experiences will be available (tentatively) Friday (3/20) by 6pm.






Virtual School Committee Meeting (Monday, 3/23/20)

A Virtual School Committee meeting, in compliance with new state-wide procedures for public meetings during this time of virus closure, will be held on Monday evening 7pm. This meeting is being held virtually in accordance with the Governor's new rules for public meetings during this time of emergency. Please check the agenda on this page:  https://natickschools.novusagenda.com/agendapublic/. Guidance for the meeting is there.







All individuals who wish to make a statement at public speak should email school committee chair Julie McDonough, at jmcdonough@natickps.org, with the statement you desire to read and she will read the statement at our meeting up to 3 minutes in accordance with our public speak policy.  The agenda will cover the updates to the educational environment due to the virus closure.  




GUIDANCE FOR SCHOOL PICKUP ACTIVITIES (TOMORROW)



As you may recall from our previous updates this week, we will be opening school foyers tomorrow, Friday (March 20), for the following actions:

    
student instrument pickup
    
student medication pickup
    
family technology device loan pickup—see pickup details below




Below we have outlined the pickup schedule. This plan adheres to current social distancing guidance and ensures there is limited time spent in the building. THIS WILL BE FOR ONE DAY ONLY AS WE ARE IN THE PROCESS OF DEEP CLEANING SCHOOLS!







School Pickup Schedule



 

All Schools (meal pickup)

8 a.m. –11 a.m., at NHS daily for breakfast and lunch pick up for students in need

Mondays for the week, 9:30am-10-:30:  pick up at Franklin Park Zoo parking lot, main entrance for Boston Students, 



 

Medication Pickup

11 a.m.–12 p.m., pre-arranged medication pick up with nurse at your child’s school



 

Instrument Pickup

11 a.m.–12 p.m., pre-arranged musical instrument pick up at your child’s school

11 a.m.–12 p.m., NHS pre-arranged instrument pick up and pre-arranged medication pick up



 

Technology Loan Pickup

11 a.m.–12 p.m., NHS pre-arranged technology pickups for families who completed our survey



 

Family Technology Device Loan Pickup (11am-12pm)

PICKUP PROCEDURES:

    
Follow the signs for ‘lunch pickup’ that direct you behind Natick High School.
    
PLEASE STAY IN YOUR CAR —our staff will come to you.
    
You will be asked to complete this pickup form. ** If you have the ability to print and complete before arriving tomorrow, it expedites the process. But we will have forms and clean pens for everyone—and the pen is yours to keep! **
    
Our tech staff WILL NOT be troubleshooting tech issues or taking any devices for repair. If you need assistance, please email (how to get tech support) and they can assist virtually. 
    
Do not come to the building for any other reason. 




Medication & Instrument Pickup (11am-12pm)

PICKUP PROCEDURES:

    
Each school will manage your drive up and pick up of materials observing social distancing procedures.  
    
Please look for signs and administration staff to direct you through pick up.  
    
    
PLEASE STAY IN YOUR CAR —our staff will come to you.
    
Do not simply exit your vehicle and seek to enter the building.  
    
No community members will be allowed in the building and staff are prepared to meet those who have contacted them only.  
    
Do not come to the building for any other reason.



REMINDERS



Educational Enrichment

We will be providing regular and robust educational enrichment online opportunities starting Wednesday, March 25, 2020, directly from your children’s teachers. In the interim, we hope you’ll use the optional enrichment activities we have made available listed below:

    
Preschool Enrichment Resources
    
K-4 Enrichment Resources
    
5-8 Enrichment Resources
    
9-12 Enrichment Resources




Virtual Library Services from Morse Institute

Our collaboration with the Morse Library is strong—they want to remind you that visiting this portion of their website:  https://morseinstitute.org/digital-collection/ebooks/  gives you access to oodles of online books, audio and video resources to get you through until next Wednesday; and all you need is a library card.



 

Don’t have a library card? No worries!  

The online registration is now up to date and immediately effective for families. 

https://library.minlib.net/selfreg



T

here is a quick and rough video on our website at: 

https://morseinstitute.org/online-library-card-registration/

 


BRIGHT SPOTS!

Although these are somber times, we have a few bright spots to share with you!



 

Scalestorm Virtual Concert

Check out our students from the a cappella group Scalestrom, who are modeling bright and shining during this time: NHS Scalestorm Virtual Concert!



Scalestorm, a student-led a cappella group from Natick High School, shared this via Julia Reinach (performance coordinator and the one who put together the video) and her co-leaders are Sam Hinrichs (music director) and Bailey Gerson (public relations officer). Scalestorm was created four years ago and they love performing around the community! During rehearsals, Scalestorm can be found telling funny stories, freestyle rapping and of course making music. They shared the following:  

“We are so happy that this was able to bring a smile to people and hopefully spread a little bit of positivity! We do have a faculty advisor at the high school, Kate Burns, and we are so grateful for her support and guidance. Additionally, we would love to thank Robbie Jacobs and the Boston Children's Chorus for teaching me (Julia)  how to do the tech side of the virtual choir. We hope you enjoy and plan to create another video like this in the future!”

 

Lilja Virtual Faculty Meeting and Appointment!

A second bright spot in our day, is that I met with the Lilja School Wednesday morning to announce the appointment of the school’s new principal, Ms. Stefani Wasik, currently principal of the Davis Thayer Elementary School in Franklin.  Ms. Wasik also served the Franklin district for five years as an assistant principal. Ms. Wasik began her career teaching second grade in Somerville, then fourth grade in Milford and Dover. She holds a Master of Educational Administration from the University of Massachusetts, Boston and a Bachelor of Arts in Elementary Education and Psychology from Saint Michael's College.



 



 

Stay Healthy,



Anna P. Nolin, Ed.D.

Superintendent  of Schools

The secret of change is to focus all of your energy, not on fighting the old, but on building the new. – Socrates 



 

Natick Public Schools

Below (see actions needed) we have listed reminders from our previous update, as they are time sensitive, to be sure anything that applies to you below is factored into your planning for this week.  







NEW INFO

Virtual School Committee meeting in compliance with new state-wide procedures for public meetings during this time of virus closure will be held Monday evening, 7pm.  Please check the agenda on this page: https://natickschools.novusagenda.com/agendapublic/







Information for public participation and observation will be shared in our Friday update.  Additionally, we will explain the upcoming online educational enrichment opportunities that will become available to our students starting Wednesday, March 25. At that time, we will have met with and trained all of our staff virtually to ensure consistent, unified support of all of our students.







Lilja Principal Announcement: We are also pleased to announce the appointment of the new Lilja Principal, Stefani Wasik!

Thank you for your continued patience and support as we navigate the closure of our schools.




 

We realize there may have been confusion about the dates listed in our update yesterday and want to clarify the change. The date for the earliest return to school is April 6, 2020, which was amended from the original statement of April 7, 2020. Read the Governor's full executive order for more information.




 

Yesterday, I shared action items for families regarding: technology and calendar surveying, medication pickup, and instrument pickup. Please see below for additional information if you were unable to review the requested actions. If you have completed the requested actions, thank you.




 

New News!

MIAA (Interscholastic Sports Association) has indicated that the start of spring sports will be delayed until at least 4/27/20.  




 

SAT/ACT College Board has emailed all registrants of cancellations and updates.  Check their websites for the latest. There’s no word yet on AP tests.




 

Many of you have emailed about senior events and prom—it is just too early to tell what will happen with these events.




 

Online Educational Enrichment Options—Coming Soon!

We will be providing regular and robust educational enrichment online opportunities starting Wednesday, March 25, 2020, directly from your children’s teachers.  




 

We ask your patience as we train our staff and create consistent video and digital options for our staff to interact with students.  



We will need families who filled out the below-included survey indicating they needed internet hotspots or technology to come in Friday for technology pick up.  You may only pick up if you indicated you needed technology in the survey. We cannot provide technology for every home.  If you have technology at home—enough to allow your children 2 -3 hours of access over a period of two days—then you have sufficient technology.  The technology needs to be able to run web applications and allow students to write documents. Google is the key web-based solution it should run.


Our collaboration with the Morse Library is strong—they want to remind you that visiting this portion of their website:  https://morseinstitute.org/digital-collection/ebooks/  gives you access to oodles of online books, audio and video resources to get you through until next Wednesday; and all you need is a library card. 



 

Don’t have a library card? No worries!  Our town library staff are working on a process—where you can obtain one online—which should be ready by Thursday (March 19) morning.




 

LIMITED SCHOOL PICKUP (THIS WEEK):

We will be opening school foyers on Friday (March 20) for the following actions: 

    
student instrument pickup, 
    
student medication pickup, and 
    
family technology device loan pickup. (More details about the technology device loan process will be shared by Thursday evening for those in need of devices.)


Below we have outlined the pickup schedule. THIS WILL BE FOR ONE DAY ONLY AS WE ARE IN THE PROCESS OF DEEP CLEANING SCHOOLS! This plan adheres to current social distancing guidance and ensures there is limited time spent in the building.




 

School Pickup Times & Schedules



All Schools (meal pickup):


    
8 a.m. –11 a.m., at NHS daily for breakfast and lunch pick up for students in need
    
Mondays for the week, 9:30am-10-:30:  pick up at Franklin Park Zoo parking lot, main entrance for Boston Students,

11 a.m.–12 p.m., pre-arranged medication pick up with nurse at your child’s school
    
11 a.m.–12 p.m., pre-arranged musical instrument pick up at your child’s school
    
11 a.m.–12 p.m., NHS pre-arranged instrument pick up and pre-arranged medication pick up


​Family Tehcnology Loan Pickup (Friday, March 20 ONLY)


    
11 a.m.–12 p.m., NHS ALL PRE-ARRANGED TECHNOLOGY PICKUPS FOR FAMILIES WHO FILLED OUT SURVEY.

Each school will manage your drive up and pick up of materials observing social distancing procedures.  Please look for signs and administration staff to direct you through pick up. Do not simply exit your vehicle and seek to enter the building.  No community members will be allowed in the building and staff are prepared to meet those who have contacted them only.

Do not come to the building for any other reason.

COMPLETE THE FAMILY TECHNOLOGY & CALENDAR  SURVEY:

If you have not done so yet, please complete our family technology and calendar survey. Your responses will help us develop planning to ensure students who need technology support are able to receive in order to participate in educational enrichment opportunities during school closure.

 

CONTACT YOUR SCHOOL NURSE REGARDING MEDICATION PICKUP:

If you have not done so yet, our Director of Nursing, Nicole Marcinkiwecz is asking parents to email your school’s nurse and indicate if you need to pick up any prescription medications that were left in the schools. Our nurse emails are listed below by school.

    
Preschool - MaryAnne Lagan (mlagan@natickps.org) 
    
Brown - Maria Chopur (mchopur@natickps.org)

Yesterday, the Governor ordered that all public and private K-12 schools be closed from March 17-April 5 with a possible return to school on April 6 , 2020.  Today, we had a successful launch to the breakfast and lunch distribution program. Many students successfully obtained critical food for their time during this closure.  This service will continue for the length of closure.

 

As a result of last night’s announcements, the MA Commissioner has also allowed us to explore new options as a result of this extended closure; the details of these educational enrichment opportunities will be forthcoming.  We must meet with our school leadership and staff as well as provide some training in order to make this process as smooth as it can be. Opportunities that will be detailed later this week should not be seen as a replication of the traditional school day, rather, a way to provide continuity of learning for our students during this uncertain time. Listed below are important updates on special education services now that guidance has been clarified at the state level.

 

Successful discussions with our Teachers' Association, The Education Association of Natick, were held today and messaging to the community will be forthcoming.  We ask your patience so we can be thorough and ensure all of our vulnerable populations are well cared for and all of our teachers are trained and informed with consistent expectations for our work with students in this period of closure.

 

A survey to families in the Natick Schools is included below. This survey will aid in logistical planning for the coming weeks.  We encourage families to fill out this survey immediately so we can provide educational enrichment opportunities in a manner that supports all students equitably.

 

ACTION NEEDED

 

COMPLETE THE FAMILY TECHNOLOGY and CALENDAR  SURVEY:

Please complete our family technology and calendar survey. Your responses will help us develop planning to ensure students who need technology support are able to receive in order to participate in educational enrichment opportunities during school closure.

​

READ THE SPECIAL EDUCATION NOTICE:

Our Assistant Superintendent for Student Services, Tim Luff, has written a letter with information for families with children receiving special education services in the district.

​

CONTACT YOUR SCHOOL NURSE REGARDING MEDICATION PICKUP:

Board of Health (BOH) calls with emergency partners (schools, all municipal partners, police, fire, business, clerk’s office, etc.) were held all weekend.  While the BOH can continue to give you guidance on social distancing, they cannot direct you. Since social distancing is the answer we have right now as a possible virus mitigation strategy I believe you should adhere to it.  Here is the latest guidelines on what communities can do: https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/downloads/community-mitigation-strategy.pdf

Messaging from the governor and from the President have also discouraged groups from meeting.



I have shared this article frequently in recent days  and I share it now with again to really emphasize the importance of social distancing: https://medium.com/@ariadnelabs/social-distancing-this-is-not-a-snow-day-ac21d7fa78b4



I cannot force anyone to do anything, but I think the guidance there is appropriate and will allow us to “flatten the curve” of this virus spread.

 

 

Ongoing Information from the Town of Natick and Board of Health

The Town of Natick and Board of Health have established an informational page regarding town-wide actions and updates related to the management of COVID-19. We encourage you to refer to this page for information: https://www.natickma.gov/1696/COVID-19-Coronavirus.

 

 

STATEMENTS FROM ACROSS THE STATE



MA 2-1-1 Hotline & Website

Massachusetts hotline 2-1-1 is operating 24/7 to provide updated information and answer questions regarding the Coronavirus. Following an automated message, please press 2-6 to access the Coronavirus section.

The hotline is also accessible through a live chat option on the Massachusetts 2-1-1 website.

 

Stay Healthy,



Anna P. Nolin, Ed.D.

Superintendent  of Schools

                        tabs: [{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl39_divTabs_0","title":"March 15, 2020","content":"
Earlier today, at a 6:30 p.m. press conference, Governor Baker announced that all public and private schools in the Commonwealth would be closed until at least April 7th. With this new guidance, over the next few days district and building administrators will be working to develop a plan for the coming weeks and we will share that plan with you as soon as possible. 

I will continue, as we have for the past two weeks, to work with an extended network of officials on all ongoing decisions.  We will continue to provide you with 5 p.m. updates daily. A meeting with the Commissioner of Education is planned for tomorrow to gain details about continuity of programs and services in the coming weeks. I anticipate sending a communication by Wednesday evening or Thursday morning to share more updates on our community and our schools. 

I hope everyone has had time for some self care and to regroup over the weekend.  I personally have appreciated the time to reconnect with my children without the crush of their typical schedule. It has also been frustrating in many ways. There is an ongoing flood of information that can be both helpful and overwhelming. I encourage people to take breaks from social media because it can lead to becoming emotionally overwhelmed and vicious malware has been providing fake updates, furthering the spread of misinformation. Please take news from official health sources and the Natick websites only.   I will communicate updates as needed, and will be selective so that you are not inundated. 

Thank you to parents and faculty who keep sharing ideas and feedback. As a caring and kind community this is a time for all of us to be at our best in supporting one another. As noted in my last communication, we welcome your comments and questions through our Speak Up, Natick! portal (http://www.natickps.org/contact_us/speakupnatick) and will review them and address them as we provide routine updates. 

Over the next three weeks we expect students to commit to stay at home to slow the spread of this outbreak.  For us to be successful everyone needs to contribute through your daily actions and by being committed to social distancing as described by the governor. If there was ever a time to be conservative in approach to social time, this is it. This article is worth reading:  This is not a snow day!  

To Staff:  I need you, my closest team, to take care of your health, keep your mood calm, and understand that as the home of innovation,  this is a challenge that the Natick Public schools can accommodate.  We are creative, flexible and innovative--with a care for relationships and our people at our core.  I can think of no other set of ingredients needed in order to make this a success.

To Students:  Many of you (almost exclusively high schoolers) have written to me about the arc of this year—EEE curtailing some events in the fall and now this curtailing events in the spring.  I understand your disappointments, and I wish I could protect you from having them, as do your parents. But at this time, everyone's health and safety is on the line.  Many generations of young people have faced these situations—from serving in war, to the draft, to dealing with economic depression. Americans have faced tough times and national crises and in persevering and working together as a country, they have built resilience and learned the value of care, community and country.  I ask you to be your best selves for your parents and community, and be the young, strong, and positive global citizens we know that you are becoming.  A community is only as strong as its most vulnerable members. Help us, help our community. 



Talk to you tomorrow,

Dr. Nolin

















Anna P. Nolin, Ed.D.

Superintendent  of Schools

The secret of change is to focus all of your energy, not on fighting the old, but on building the new. – Socrates

Thank you for your continued attention as we work with Town partners to navigate the evolving COVID-19 situation in our community. We’re writing with further information related to school closure, please see below for details.





Updates from Governor Baker, today, were difficult to decipher—large crowds of 250 or more have been banned, but schools remaining open is acceptable?  Therefore, I am sharing two messages (below) from our professional state superintendent networks to show you the solidarity and certainty with which educational leaders are trying to slow the spread.  We have even begun to look into contracting with professionals in the field as a tri-county region to gain more information on managing this epidemic.





Additionally, discussions with the MA Commissioner of Education focused on how to handle MCAS, working to end victim bullying, and he supported the decision that—in communities like ours who have experienced cross-community contamination—closure was indeed the next step.  We are pushing MA DPH for guidance on next steps for mitigation and management. 





UPDATES FROM NATICK





Information from the Town of Natick and Board of Health

The Town of Natick and Board of Health have established an informational page regarding town-wide actions and updates related to the management of COVID-19. We encourage you to refer to this page for information: https://www.natickma.gov/1696/COVID-19-Coronavirus.





Upcoming Communication from the District

    
Our Director of Nursing, Nicole Marcinkiwecz, will be in touch next week about managing medication pick up if you need medications that were left in the schools.  
    
Our Assistant Superintendent for Student Services, Tim Luff, will be in touch with out-of-district special education parents about their school status and transportation as those arrangements vary by site.
    
Our Director of K12 Music, Craig Chisholm, will be in touch about instrumental music lessons and how rescheduling will be handled.






Student Enrichment During Closure

As stated in our message on March 12, 2020, optional enrichment activities for younger students related to skill-building at home are available:

    
K-4 Enrichment Resources
    
5-8 Enrichment Resources


These experiences are not mandatory and are not considered instruction. However, for all students K-12, there will be no assignments or additional learning provided by the district or teachers. This is being done in the interest of ensuring equity of access to remain in line with our district core values. Additionally, we are not allowed to provide any digital or remote learning opportunities to replace in-person teaching during this closure, based on guidance from the MA Commissioner of Education.





STATEMENTS FROM ACROSS THE STATE





Massachusetts Association of School Superintendents

Our superintendents are facing uncharted times. COVID-19 has created major disruptions to our way of life as we see many organizations, businesses and education communities changing daily operations. During the past two weeks, we have seen increasing concerns with the care and well being of our populations. In our schools, superintendents are hearing from parents, local Board of Health and community medical experts. As such, our superintendents are in close communication with neighboring colleagues and other resources as they consider next steps in their decision making.





Unfortunately, during the past two weeks, we have received little or no guidance from state and federal organizations. In the lack of clear, definitive guidelines, the Superintendents are collaborating to provide leadership during this critical time and to ensure the safety and well being of their communities.





Yesterday, superintendents in various areas of the Commonwealth used local information and decided to close schools for 1 – 2 weeks until we have more understanding of how Coronavirus evolves. Many additional schools will be exercising this decision today and early next week.





M.A.S.S. has supported these decisions. Our superintendents have no higher priority than student safety. These closures will allow the opportunity to evaluate local conditions and allow the medical community time to better advise future decisions.





Tri-County Roundtable

In addition to the MA Association of School Superintendents (MASS) releasing a statement, the superintendents and executive directors of the school districts and special education collaboratives of the Tri-County Roundtable have developed a coordinated plan to close all of our schools for at least one week, starting Monday, March 16, 2020, in response to the coronavirus pandemic. 





The Tri-County Roundtable is a professional association comprised of the following school districts and special education collaboratives: ACCEPT Collaborative, Ashland, Dedham, Dover Sherborn, Framingham, Franklin, Holliston, Hopkinton, King Philip Regional, Maynard, Medfield, Medway, Millis, Natick, Needham, Norfolk, Norfolk County Agricultural School, Plainville, South Middlesex Regional Vocational Technical School, The Education Cooperative (TEC), Tri County Regional Vocational School, Walpole, Wellesley, Westwood, and Wrentham.





We decided this in consultation with our local boards of health and medical and scientific experts in our communities. Several factors influenced our decision. We reviewed the recommendations from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Massachusetts Department of Public Health, and Massachusetts Department of Elementary and Secondary Education. We considered the impact of the virus on the vulnerable members of our communities. Finally, we recognized the challenges of fostering learning in the atmosphere of uncertainty created by this unprecedented situation. 





Each superintendent is expected to communicate this information and any updates about closure to you in the coming weeks.





Making Isolation Beautiful

In parts of Italy, total lockdown of citizens is occurring to slow virus spread.  Despite tough times, people can always make beauty. Check this out!  





Have a video or picture of something beautiful happening as a result of our unexpected family time? Share it with us using SPEAK UP, NATICK! (select ‘District’ as the school/office). 





Have a good weekend,



Anna P. Nolin, Ed.D.

Superintendent  of Schools
